text:
Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: John William Hubbard

Present Address: 212 Main St., Saskatoon

Pioneer Address: 812 Main St., Saskatoon

Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1894

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1921, and most of the questions are about their early period. Although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.,
Saskatchewan Archives Office,

No. 5
1. In the last few years, how many houses were near enough to you for visiting back and forth?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? (Include family and friends)

3. Did you usually visit on Sundays or other days?

4. Invitations were often written to other houses, or was visiting done without an invitation, and if so, what was the reason?

5. How many of these were bachelor's houses?

6. How many of these were bachelors' homes?

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there any parties, etc., that drew a crowd in houses? Especially, how about Fourth of July?

8. What was the favorite summer activity? Why did you choose it?

9. Did you follow any kind of formal schedule, such as going by turn from one house to another at definite times—every two weeks, once a month, etc.?
RESIDENTIAL VISITATION, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Use always, rarely, never.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday or other days?

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Use usually, rarely, never.

5. What time of the day did you go - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.?

6. What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

7. How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly?

8. If so, what refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in unexpectedly?

9. Usually, everyone had bread and a drink brought during such a group.

10. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to look after the house?

11. Did you attend parties at other homes frequently?

12. Did you attend parties at your own home frequently?

13. Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "theme" were for, and how often they were held.

14. How did the family respond to these parties?

15. In the earliest years that you were here, were there any parties, what kind were they, and how often were they held?

16. Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.?
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. Include also the school questionnaires. Give dates.

9. When was your first community hall built?

What material was it made of? How large was it?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of boxes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you liked it there, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.? )

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8), and TO) did the entire family attend?

In the town or village did you take to the dance hall or to the school house and children provided for?

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

Was there any dancing between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Some who frequented parties, either as an entertainer in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

And playing was usually at home? Why?
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

We had a tennis club organized in 1901, had 6 tennis courts. 24 members met at school twice a week & kept equipment there. Courts were near us. We had tennis club banquet & dance yearly in school for about 5 years. Also cricket club had a dance or two a year. In a big picnic year, at 1st July, church ladies would have Roy's annual pie socials.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

The school houses were the only buildings in district here that would house a gathering until 1908 when there was no United Church. An Anglican was opened 1916 July 26th.

9. When was your first community hall built?

What material was it made of? How large was it?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?).

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for?

In the homes it was OK to take babies but school houses not suitable.

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

Usually neighbors doubled up & went in loads in sleighs not to have too many horses or the horses were taken to nearby farms.

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Bridge, Pinochle, Cribbage, Nap, Poker, Whist.

Was there card playing for a prize? No.

What dances were popular?

Square dances or Quadrilles, Walzing, and a lot of other dances.

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

People often went to enjoy the social times & music if they did not dance. Only small house dances until after 1910.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

Card playing was usually at homes & small parties.
12. What activities or formalities, or "games," do you remember in small towns, such as picnics, etc.? Do you remember in small towns, such as picnics, etc., that you remember?

13. Was the atmosphere known to your community? No

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember.

In visiting or social gatherings, there were popular activities and the approximate dates whenever you can remember.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember?

A local club called "Elks Club" or "Lions Club," P.A. (Penn.) 1896-1897

16. Was there a Sabbath-school prayer meeting local in your community?

Yes, we had a daily prayer in the evening and Sunday service.

17. Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

18. Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

19. How many women belonged? How often did it meet?

How many women belonged? How often did it meet?

20. What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

21. When was it organized? About 1910.

When was it organized? About 1910.

22. Describe what you remember about churches, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

Describe what you remember about churches, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

23. Was the atmosphere known to your community? No
12. What attempts at formality, or manners, do you remember in small towns such as those you visited? How did people behave? What was considered polite behavior?

13. Was there a club in your community? Describe what you remember about it.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any places or activities not already mentioned that were popular at parties, etc., and give approximate dates whenever you can when these changes in social life took place.

In early 90's there were quite a few English names. Men who were fond of hunting could be found throughout the town. Also some farms and lots of orchards at Clarence in Hall in Town. The English and old country people did not mix with the German farmers but kept to their own good town.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you remember being established in your community?

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged? How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

16. Was there a Grain Growers' Club in your community?

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged? How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? When was it organized? Approximately how many women belonged to it? Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1945, listing the name of each club, organization, and time period (e.g., 1925-1935, old people only) in one relatively small area for emphasis within a short statement. (Note: If there is no information available, say so.)

22. What games did girls play in summer (jumping rope, play house, etc.)?

CHILDCARE GAMES

What were the slides about?

Some time and again children and some kids would come around and make some noise.

Did you often have magic lantern shows?

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

Would be a good house.

an annual day in four quarters and numerous

of a night.

This means were commonly used by organizations for raising money.

We had a great club was organized about 1910 in our town

We were a very small club and found, would play at and around

April 1910 and a family friend, would have been convinced

A golf club was founded about 1910 in our town

The town was a small town and known as fairly new and hopeful

Each fall and feet and knees in January the county

I am unable now to play a game in April and a following

You had a very good fellow that ended up after 1910 surviving
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1930, listing the name of each, their purpose, whether organized for altruistic or selfish purposes only in our relatively small area (for example, women's clubs, etc.), or was centered in the town or village stage and included the surrounding communities. If there is space in the church question, list organizations.

There was a cricket club, which could get together every Saturday afternoon for practice. They could also play a match on a Fourth of July or holiday. There was also a baseball club, which played at night. The town also had a football team, which played about once a month.

What games were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

At night, there was a fairground and moonlight shows.

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Have you attended to have general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? By a travelling missionary? By a local minister or teacher? Special lecturers, etc., where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Ministers often had lantern slides and teachers would help with a program if weather permits.

Would be a full house.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

Some times about aquiculture and some Bible lands

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (jumping rope, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)?

That games did girls play in summer (skipping rope, play house, etc.)?

A few flew kites but mostly ball & turkey.

Skipping & ball, cricket for tall.

Picnics and Sports

Homemade Lemonade, Tea, Sandwiches & Cake & Cookies.

1 o'clock till dark about 7, folks had to go home to milk the cows.
33. Describe any features of this plant which you remember as outstanding.

34. Describe any different kinds of plants which you knew of in the early days, such as a large community plate, school or Sunday School plates, neatly painted, etc., tell about any differences in numbers attending activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in places since the first years? Give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people). Normally young people attended once

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams? How long did it continue?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1940, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities—played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centers, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

1899 - Hockey & Curling
31. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

32. Name the various different kinds of picnics which you know of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnic, family picnic, etc. Tell what differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drinks, when held, etc.,

There was also a large community picnic field

33. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

34. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (sex, women mostly, young people), mostly young people & older ones

35. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year?

How long did it continue?

36. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914 playing date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities—played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger areas, etc.

37. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

1899 skating & curling
40. When did an annual "report day" become established in your community? 

41. Did it arise out of or replace an earlier community practice? 

42. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known book clubs, guilds or other literary clubs names and dates. 

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them? 

What kind of books and how many? 

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors? 

We often exchanged a few books. 

45. Did you buy many books after you came here? Give details. 

Not for a few years.

Give titles and dates.

GENERAL

HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS.
